Introduction

An umbilical hernia is a protrusion of intraabdominal contents (eg, omentum, small intestine) through an open umbilical ring.  Umbilical hernias are common and can be congenital or acquired.  Umbilical hernias often resolve spontaneously, but surgical repair may be required to prevent complications.

Pathogenesis



The umbilical ring is an opening in the abdominal fascia that allows the umbilical vessels to pass.  All neonates are born with an open umbilical ring, and the umbilical ring normally closes as the rectus abdominis muscles grow together soon after birth.  The fascial layers fuse to form the linea alba, or a midline band of fibrous tissues.  Incomplete closure of the umbilical ring allows intraabdominal contents (eg, bowel) to herniate through the abdominal musculature, resulting in a congenital umbilical hernia.



Umbilical hernias may also be acquired due to increased intraabdominal pressure (eg, ascites, chronic cough, constipation) or weakening of the abdominal fascia (eg, previous abdominal surgeries).



This article focuses on congenital umbilical hernias.

Risk factors



The primary risk factor for congenital umbilical hernias is premature birth, likely related to weak abdominal musculature.  Congenital umbilical hernias most commonly occur in isolation but can be associated with many conditions, including trisomy 21, trisomy 18, congenital hypothyroidism, Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome, and certain mucopolysaccharidoses.

Clinical presentation



A congenital umbilical hernia presents as a soft, bulging mass at the umbilicus that is covered by skin.  The mass becomes more prominent with increased intraabdominal pressure (eg, crying, straining).  In most cases, the umbilical hernia can be easily reduced (

Differential diagnosis



The differential diagnosis includes other congenital abdominal wall defects (

), including:



  • Omphalocele (
    figure 1
    ):  During midgut development, abdominal contents undergo rapid growth and subsequent physiologic herniation, followed by physiologic reduction.  Failed reduction results in the formation of an omphalocele, or a midline sac that contains intraabdominal contents covered by peritoneum (ie, no skin, fascia, or muscle) with the umbilical cord at the apex.
  • Gastroschisis (
    figure 2
    ):  A full-thickness abdominal wall defect that allows the bowel to eviscerate into the amniotic cavity.  This defect is typically located adjacent to the umbilicus (ie, umbilicus is unaffected), and the bowel is uncovered.

Diagnosis



A congenital umbilical hernia is a clinical diagnosis based primarily on physical examination.  Further evaluation (eg, imaging) is not necessary in otherwise asymptomatic patients with reducible hernias.

Management



Management of asymptomatic congenital umbilical hernias involves reassurance and observation, with spontaneous resolution often occurring by age 3-5.  Surgical repair may be considered for congenital umbilical hernias that:



  • Persist beyond age 5.
  • Become incarcerated or strangulated.
  • Are large (ie, >1.5 cm in diameter) or have significant skin protrusion.
  • Are associated with an underlying condition (eg, trisomy 21, hypothyroidism).

Prognosis



Congenital umbilical hernias are benign, and the prognosis is excellent, with most cases resolving spontaneously as the rectus abdominis muscles grow and fascial layers fuse by age 5.  Complications are rare and include incarceration (contents unable to be reduced) and strangulation (ie, compromised vascular supply to incarcerated contents).

Summary



An umbilical hernia is a protrusion of intraabdominal contents (eg, omentum, small intestine) through an open umbilical ring.  Umbilical hernias can be congenital or acquired.  Congenital umbilical hernias often resolve spontaneously, but surgical repair may be necessary to prevent complications (eg, incarceration, strangulation) (
